faq.title: Who is behind impresso?
faq.summary: The impresso project is a Swiss-Luxembourgish research project dedicated to the computational enrichment of historical newspapers and the development of new workflows for (digital) historians in a newly designed user interface.
description: The objective of the impresso project is to enable critical text mining of newspaper archives with an interdisciplinary consortium implementing a technological framework to extract, process, link, and explore data from print media archives.

The core team consists of computational linguists, designers/developers as well as historians based at the DHLAB of the École polytechnique fédérale de Lausanne (EPFL), the Institute of Computational Linguistics at the University of Zurich and the Luxembourg Centre for Contemporary and Digital History (C2DH). The project is funded by the Swiss National Science foundation (Grant CR- SII5_173719).

We built our newspaper corpus with the help of content providing partners, these are the Swiss National Library, the National Library of Luxembourg, State Archives of Valais, Swiss Economic Archives, Le Temps and Neue Zürcher Zeitung.

We are further supported by a team of academic partners:
  • François Vallotton (Full Professor at the University of Lausanne),
  • Raphaëlle Ruppen Coutaz (Lecturer at the University of Lausanne),
  • Frédéric Clavert (Assistant Professor at C2DH) and
  • Enrico Natale (Managing Director infoclio.ch).
Finally, a group of associated researchers have committed to using impresso for their research and provide valuable feedback to us.
Take a look at our project homepage for more details.

faq.title: Which newspapers do you have in your corpus?
faq.summary: All titles are listed on the Newspaper page.
description: In a nutshell, the impresso corpus contains titles from the historical newspaper collections of the Swiss National Library, the National Library of Luxembourg, the Media Center and the Valais State Archives, and the Swiss Economic Archives. The archives of the journals Le Temps and of the Neue Zürcher Zeitung are also in impresso.
We recommend that you take a closer look at the Newspapers page.

faq.title: Why can’t I see everything? How do I get access to the full corpus?
faq.summary: Unrestricted access is only possible for the subset of newspapers which are in the public domain. To gain access to the whole collection, you need to sign a Non Disclosure Agreement (NDA).
description: From a legal perspective, there is a risk that content creators could make claims to their rights to texts and images which were published in a newspaper. This is why unrestricted access is only possible for the subset of newspapers which are in the public domain. To gain access to the whole collection, you need to sign a Non Disclosure Agreement (NDA). We will provide you with a user account upon reception of your signed NDA.
Please see the Terms of Use to learn more about the usage rights for the impresso corpus.

faq.title: I would like to give feedback
faq.summary: To leave us feedback, please click on the black envelope on the lower right of the interface or email us at info@impresso-project.ch. We will get back to you soon after.
description: The impresso interface remains under active development and we will add new features to the interface in the common months. We always look forward to hearing from you and to learn how you made use of impresso’s tools. To leave us feedback, please click on the black envelope on the lower right of the interface or email us at info@impresso-project.ch. We will get back to you soon after.

faq.title: Can I use impresso interface in the classroom?
faq.summary: Yes, with the same restrictions as for other uses and we would be very happy to hear about your experience!
description: All material restrictions apply equally in a teaching context, please see the Terms of Use page. It could be a good opportunity to introduce legal matters related to primary sources and research data to the students.

faq.title: What are the copyrights of the newspapers accessible through the impresso interface?
faq.summary: Newspapers accessible through the impresso interface are under different copyrights.
description: Conditions of use are set at the issue level of each newspaper. You can find this information a) on the individual newspaper page, b) upon download, for each item of the CSV file. To select articles belonging to a particular category of license, choose the relevant category in "filter by access rights".

The majority of them are free of use for personal and academic use (see the ‘Personal and Academic use’ section in the Terms of Use). Others are in the public domain and are not subject to any restrictions (‘Public’). Newspapers from the National Library of Luxembourg can be used without restriction up to 1877, only for personal and academic use onwards.

faq.title: What do you mean by ‘impresso material’?
faq.summary: This includes all images, text, metadata, the semantic annotations and the interface.
description:
We distinguish between the following assets:
  • newspaper images and text, subject to copyrights (see the rights statements pages)
  • newspaper metadata, free for use under a CC BY 4.0 license
  • newspaper metadata, free for use under a CC BY 4.0 license
  • semantic annotations, free for use under a CC BY SA 4.0 license (will be released at the end of the project)
  • impresso interface, including front end design and back end database and system architecture, under a GNU AGPLv3 license (will be released at the end of the project)

faq.title: How can I cite impresso?
faq.summary: When quoting individual articles, mention the online version with the URL and the date of access. Click on more for some example.
description: In the context of digitised materials, it is important to quote the portal in which you found a particular source. Applied to newspapers, it means that one has to add to the traditional information on the author, article and newspaper title, the URL and the date of accessing the digitised source. For instance, to quote an article intitled 'Un mythe toujours intact?', written by Corinne Chuard, published in the newspaper l'Impartial on the 3.08.1987, retrieved on the 3.08.2018, one might use the following model to refer to it: Chuard, Corinne. ‘Un mythe toujours intact?’, L’Impartial, 03-Aug-1987, p. 2. Available: https://impresso-project.ch/app/issue/IMP-1987-08-03-a/page/IMP-1987-08-03-a-p0002/article/IMP-1987-08-03-a-i0019. Accessed: 03-Aug-2018.

To refer to the project, please use the following quote:
impresso. Media Monitoring of the Past. Supported by the Swiss National Science Foundation under grant CR- SII5_173719, 2019. https://impresso-project.ch.

faq.title: Can I cite and/or display impresso newspaper articles on my blog or website? Can I cite impresso material in my thesis or in a scientific publication?
faq.summary: Yes, you can cite all impresso material, in accordance with customary scholarly and scientific practices. One exception: images
description: when re-using an illustration or photograph printed in a newspaper provided by the National Library of Luxembourg, you must obtain their permission beforehand and email them at licensing@uni.lu

faq.title: Do you have an API?
faq.summary: For advanced users we provide access via an API.
description: If this is of interest to you, please contact us at info@impresso-project.ch.

faq.title: Am I allowed to automatically mass-download newspaper images and texts?
faq.summary: No, downloading large numbers of newspaper items that are (possibly) protected by copyright is not permitted.
description: Subject to conditions, bulk use of digital documents is possible for scientific research purposes. For more information, please contact us at info@impresso-project.ch.

faq.title: Can I download part of the data?
faq.summary: Yes, subject to our terms of use, up to 10,000 items can be downloaded (metadata, text, and annotations) and used for academic or personal purposes.
description: Should you need a larger, custom export, please email us at info@impresso-project.ch.

faq.title: Why are some pages or issues not searchable?
faq.summary: We use state-of-the-art tools to improve the quality of the OCR and to identify persons and locations. Inevitably, they sometimes fail and make mistakes which we need to remain aware of.
description: There is no such thing as a perfect corpus and ours is no exception. To give you a better sense of what you can expect to find in our corpus, we display the total count of pages and issues per year in the Newspaper overview. If you do date-specific queries, we recommend that you check how much content is missing. In a future release we will also display missing content per individual newspaper.
'

There are multiple reasons which cause missing content:
  • Digitisation: Not all issues were available for digitisation by the libraries due to incomplete collections; in other cases single pages or complete issues were missed during the digitisation. In this case, the folder structure on the hard disks we received suggests that there should be an issue but there are no corresponding files. In other cases, newspaper pages were digitized successfully but not subjected to text recognition (OCR). You can find these pages in the interface by browsing an issue, but not through a search.
  • Transfer: The journey of digitized materials is quite fragmented in both space and time, with various transfers at different times among several partners (e.g. the library, the OCR company, the hosting company, and finally, us). When discovering non readable .zip files in the sources we received on hard drives, it was not possible to recover them nor to know where the corruption came from. Full traceability is still a challenge.

faq.title: Where can I analyse the metadata of my collections or queries?
faq.summary: The Inspect and Compare page enables to take a bird’s eye view of a list of articles from their metadata and NLP annotation perspective: how many hits per newspaper title, locations, persons.
description: As all items of the impresso collection have been extracted with the same processing and based on the same type of metadata, one can extract these information and use them to inspect from a distance a list of articles and compare them. All metadata, (date of publication, language or newspaper title…) and all NLP annotations (persons, locations and topics) are data that link and cluster the articles. We can group or differentiate the articles based on these information (compare) and have a first impression of what a list of articles contains (inspect).

In the inspect view, you can focus on the information each column contains. The information about a collection of articles or search results are presented in the form of lists, in three columns. Start with selecting in column ‘A’, a query or an existing collection, to be contrasted with a query or another existing collection.

To compare collections, select the ‘collection’ tab and then select from the list, the collection you want to inspect and compare. Go then to the column ‘B’ and select another collection in the same way. In the middle column, you will see the overlapping metadata: the number of articles present in both collections, distributed by newspaper titles, named entities, topics, etc. Scroll down the lists to inspect individual filters. You can also inspect queries: in column ‘A’ and ‘B’, type a keyword in the search box and limit the scope of this query by adding filters.

Keep in mind that the display of categories like Persons, Topics or Locations, is limited to 10 options by default. However, you can browse to the next 10 most relevant results by using the pagination at the bottom of these segments. In the central column, we display the overlap of the two chosen queries or collections, which is practically another query, adding all the filters from the two other columns. You can open this overlapping query in the search environment to read the articles beneath.

In the compare view, you can focus on how both columns overlap. This view follows similar principles as the inspect view, but focuses on the overlapping items per each category. You can choose to display the scale of comparison as linear or square root, which allows for an easier comparison of heterogeneous sizes. You can also change the measure of the comparison from absolute to percentage. It means that you can see either how many individual articles are present in both queries and how many overlap or show what is the proportion of both queries that overlap. Changing this will change the order of elements being displayed: in absolute numbers, you will see first for instance the newspapers with the most articles while in the percentage view, you will see first the newspapers with the highest proportion of overlapping articles in both columns. Switching scales and sorting may help you keep track of the context of your queries or collections.

faq.title: Limited search filters for this query
How does the image search work?
faq.summary: We retrieve images which are similar to each other.
description: This feature is the result of a collaboration with our colleague Benoit Seguin, who developed novel deep learning techniques for searching large-scale image collections and successfully applied them to the collection of images in our corpus. This yielded visual signatures for each recognized picture in our corpus. We use these signatures to retrieve images which are similar to each other.

Use the image search tab to search within captions of detected images/pictures. Once you select an image, all similar images will be displayed. Alternatively, you can upload your own images to identify identical or similar ones in our corpus.
Further reading: B. L. A. Seguin, “Making large art historical photo archives searchable,” 2018, https://infoscience.epfl.ch/record/261212.

faq.title: The search image page has limited search filters
faq.summary: Available filters: by publication date, by newspaper titles and whether retrieved images are on the front page

faq.title: How to make AND and OR queries?
faq.summary: Calibrate your query of exact matches of several keywords (OR), expand it with other keywords (AND) or with similar words (generated by word embeddings).
description: By default, the keywords you type in the search box will yield articles in which this keyword has been detected by the automatic text recognition. Beyond that, you have several options to narrow down or expand your query.

First, you can choose where to look for the word: in the article content or title. Then, you can add several keywords, one after the other (press ‘Enter’ after each one or select in the autofill) and choose how the results of each keyword will overlap:
  • To narrow down your result list, you can choose to include ‘all of the following’, which will return articles containing all of the listed keywords (AND)
  • To expand your result list, you can choose to include ‘at least one of the following, which will return articles containing at least one of the listed keywords. To do so, you need to add the keywords you want to link with OR in the same search pill.
  • To exclude a keyword from your results, simply add your keyword in the search box and select ‘NOT contains’. You also need to group the words you want to exclude in the same search pill.

Since the default behaviour is performing an exact match, you can find alternative spellings, frequent OCR mistakes or synonyms with the button ‘find similar’. This panel displays suggestions produced by the word embeddings, of the last added keyword.
For instance, if you search for ‘virus’ in French, it will suggest ‘virale’, a variation on the same word or ‘bactérie’, a related word.

Keep in mind that the exact match setting does not allow to truncate keywords (e.g. search for ‘europ*’ to retrieve ‘europe’, ‘european’, ‘europeans’, etc.). To collect the variations of a keyword, use the option ‘find similar’.

Each time you add or remove a keyword, your choices are summarised in the ‘apply changes’ button, that you need to click, to validate your changes. You can search for several words at once, or short sentences, but the probability of matches, due to OCR issues will be reduced. These features are also available for topics, named entities, or the metadata filters (newspaper titles etc.).

faq.title: What do ngrams show?
faq.summary: Display the number of times a given keyword is mentioned in impresso collection at a specific date, that is, the “raw” hit of a given keyword not grouped by article, calculated for each year.
description: The ngram viewer displays n consecutive tokens, e.g. unique keywords. Currently the ngram viewer displays unigrams, e.g. single words but will be expanded to display bigrams, e.g. two consecutive keywords, for instance ‘Spanish flu’.

Many processing steps are required to display the total count of a given word in the impresso collection. In order to count the mentions of a given word, first all items (articles, advertisements, obituaries, etc.) have to be tokenized, that means finding all unique words in the whole collection.

After this step, only the potentially relevant keywords are selected, all stop words or contentless words such as prepositions, definite articles (le, la, les, der, die, das) are removed. This is particularly important to keep in mind when searching for bigrams: e.g. to finding the bigram of ‘l’Europe des Lumières’ becomes possible, since only ‘Europe’ and ‘Lumières’ has been retained.

Then, the tokens are lemmatised, that is, we group together the inflected forms of each word). Finally, the token count can be filtered by all usual filters: date, language, newspaper title, topic, person etc.

faq.title: This ngram trends page has limited search filters
faq.summary: At the moment we are not allowing to filter by full text search queries while getting ngram frequencies.

faq.title: How is it plotted?
faq.summary: SUM displays the absolute frequencies of result hits, whereas % shows the relative number of hits, compared to all articles from the impresso corpus.
description: The highest result per year is displayed in number. The impresso interface groups the results per article, so the displayed frequency is the count of all articles containing at least one occurrence of the keyword. In other words, it is not the raw number of hits for the searched key-word, but the number of hits grouped by articles, as shown in the search summary. For instance, a query for Einstein’ returns 8 967 articles. These 8 967 articles contain 13 535 individual hits of ‘Einstein’. An item is included in the search when it contains at least one character, this means that the search is conducted also within advertisements and tables when they contain text.

faq.title: How is the article type identified?
faq.summary: After the scanning of the newspapers, during the Optical Layout Recognition, some particular object types have been identified and tagged as such: articles, obituaries etc.
description: The digitisation of the newspapers has been supervised by the partners of impresso and carried out by external service providers for most cases. Each partner defined the categories of newspapers article that the external service provider should tag. We inherited these categories, that are dependent on each newspaper title and each partner. For instance, the National Library of Luxembourg provided newspapers with articles tagged as obituaries, advertisements for most newspapers and for some newspapers, the weather section could be identified. The identification is based on visual features that change rapidly over time and between the newspaper titles: the visual presentation of obituaries is not constant over decades and relies therefore on intensive manual annotation. This makes the segmentation of the newspapers into different article types very costly and difficult to reuse from one newspaper title to another.

faq.title: What does the missing pages or issues indicate?
faq.summary: Errors may occur in the process of digitisation: some files may be corrupted and therefore cannot be used for full text search.
description: The newspaper digitisation has been carried out by external service providers; the files created in this process for each page and each newspaper issue may suffer from their transfer from one server to another. When copying these files anew, one can count the number of files that cannot be read anymore or that are simply empty. In the newspaper titles’ overview, we display the proportion of unavailable files per year (when applicable), measured in number of pages or issues. You may notice a difference of temporal distribution of the missing files. This is simply because the pages are contained in a folder that constitutes a newspaper issue. A missing issue corresponds to a corrupted archive, while missing pages correspond to empty files within an issue folder. These numbers are not indicative of the missing physical issues in the providers’ collection (e.g. a newspaper issue that was printed, but was not preserved in the physical archive). They do not indicate the number of issues that could not be printed for material reasons (strike, shortage of paper, censorship etc.) nor they are an indication of the proportion of newspapers that have been digitised, compared to all historical newspapers.

faq.title: How to navigate the topic graph?
faq.summary: Explore the topics, how they related to one another, for the whole impresso collection or for your query.
description: There are two main uses of the visualisation of topics: one where you explore the topics as such and another where you filter out the topics based on a query. We will describe both now.
Exploring the topics

On the left side, all topics are displayed and searchable: when you type a word here, you are looking for words contained in each topic. From that list, you can click on the eye icon to highlight the topic in the graph (in blue). You can also click on a given topic and go to the topic page, where you will see the distribution of that topic over time, the most relevant articles for that topic. From that page, you can add the topic to a query: this means that when you return to the search page, this topic will be activated as a filter.

Back to the topic page: on the right side, you can see a graph displaying how topics related to one another. You can choose to color the topics by language (this means all the topics from one language will share the same color) or by community (this means that the one color describes one computed topic model.

The nodes’ sizes can then be adjusted according to various measures: you can choose to highlight the quantity of articles each topic ‘contains’ with ‘countItem’ or highlight the connectivity of topics with their ‘degree’.
Interact with the graph

• Hover with your cursor over a topic node to see its description.
  • Zoom in the graph with your scroller.
  • Click and drag nodes to reshape their position on the graph.
  • Reset all to return to the original version of the graph, and start again.
Exploring the topics of your query

If you have started a query on the search page, you can choose to use this as a filter for the topic graph. This means that all the elements described earlier are still valid but what is displayed does not anymore reflect the whole impresso collection but is tailored to your query.

For instance, if you search for ‘vaccination’ on the topic page, you will have two topics containing this word. Whereas if you search for ‘vaccination’ on the search page and use this search as a filter for the topic graph, you will have 212 topics related to the articles containing the word ‘vaccination’.

faq.title: Filter the list of results by article length
faq.summary: Article length is measured in number of tokens. The histogram shows the number of articles grouped by similar length intervals

faq.title: What is an error ID?
faq.summary: The error ID is a unique identifier for each error in the impresso corpus.
description: The error ID is a unique identifier for each error in the impresso corpus. It is used to track the error and to provide feedback to the Impresso team. If you encounter an error, please report it to us quoting the error ID or taking a screenshot of the page where the error occurred.

faq.title: What are OCR, OLR and METS/ALTO??
faq.summary: OCR and OLR describe the automated recognition of text and article layouts. METS and ALTO are xml standards used to store this information together with other metadata.
description: Optical Character Recognition (OCR) describes the automated identification of letters in scanned images. As a byproduct, most OCR tools also detect other elements in a scanned image, for example images or tables. The OCR software typically preserves the coordinates for each letter on the scanned image. These coordinates are the basis for the yellow highlighting for keywords in the facsimile view of an article. Optical Layout Recognition (OLR) identifies article boundaries on a page which we highlight in blue in impresso.

All this information is stored in standardized forms. A frequently used format is METS/ALTO XML developed by the Library of Congress, where METS (Metadata Encoding and Transmission Schema) stores information such as article titles and the publication date of the issue and ALTO (Analyzed Layout and Text Object) contains the information on the position of letters, images and article boundaries. To summarise, digitisation produces three layers of new information that shape its later use:
  • OCR creates keyword-searchable text
  • OLR identifies the organisation of articles on a page. Search within articles becomes possible as well as the classification of article types, e.g. advertisements or obituaries
  • METS/ALTO stores the location of characters on the scanned image and additional metadata.

The quality of text and layout recognition can vary significantly between newspapers. Most critical are the materials on which they are applied: Paper scans in high resolution are for example better suited than scans from microfilm in lower resolutions. At the same time, tools for OCR and OLR continue to improve and some libraries regularly re-OCR and re-OLR their collections.

Digitized text organized in article boundaries is the foundation of the text processing we undertake as part of the impresso project. Variations in the quality of the underlying text also negatively affects the quality of topic modeling, named entity recognition, text reuse and word embeddings.
Finally, the impresso team from Zurich also demonstrated that for lower quality scans, techniques used for Handwritten Text Recognition (HTR) can outperform standard OCR tools.

Further reading:
  • 'Optical Character Recognition.' In Wikipedia, October 12, 2019. https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Optical_character_recognition&oldid=920815843.
  • ALTO specifications, https://www.loc.gov/standards/alto/description.html
  • METS specifications, http://www.loc.gov/standards/mets
  • Ströbel, Phillip Benjamin; Clematide, Simon: Improving OCR of Black Letter in Historical Newspapers: The Unreasonable Effectiveness of HTR Models on Low-Resolution Images

faq.title: What is Named Entity Processing?
faq.summary: Named entities correspond to elements of interest that appear in texts, usually of type Person, Location or Organisation.
description: They are referential units which underlie the meaning of texts. Their definition is quite vague, but as a rule of thumb, they correspond more or less to proper names. The important criteria is here the name, which acts as a ‘rigid designator’: to differentiate for instance a common definite description  such as ‘the pope’ referring to any pope, from the mention of a particular named entity such as ‘Pope Francis’.

In a first step, Named Entity Recognition and Classification (NERC) automatically detects  and categorize mentions of e.g. a person in a text. For now we make use of a rule-based system, and will also apply machine learning techniques at a later stage. A rule-based system tries to recognize patterns based on morphological and lexical clues. For example, the pattern  [uppercase token + uppercase letter + punctuation + known surname] could recognize ‘George W. Bush’. A machine learning-based system requires, for its part, a large number of annotated entities in texts (examples of persons, institutions and locations), from which it will “learn” what they look like and how to identify them. In a second step we try to link entity mentions to a knowledge base containing entities (with their unique identifiers). We use AIDA Light for the linking and Wikidata as the reference knowledge base. This allows us to link one mention of a person named ‘Winston Churchill’ to the former British prime minister across the corpus (when it works). Finally, in the near future we will be looking for relations between entities, for example  a born_in relation between a person and a location entity, colleague_of between two persons, alma_mater between a person and an organisation (in this case could be of subtype ‘Educational’).
These are baselines, and the improvement of automated recognition and linking of named entities in historical texts is one of impresso’s research objectives.

Further reading:
  • Impresso blog post: Named entity processing in a nutshell, https://impresso-project.ch/news/2018/06/12/tradingzone-ner.html
  • If you wish a lightweight introduction to Named Entity Processing for Digital Humanities, have a look at the tutorial we provided during the DH 2019 conference in Utrecht: https://github.com/impresso/named-entity-tutorial-dh2019
  • An old reference, but which gives a nice overview: Nadeau, David, and Satoshi Sekine. 'A survey of named entity recognition and classification'. Lingvisticae Investigationes 30.1 (2007): 3-26.
  • For those who are curious about the concept of named entities, a longer document (in French): Les Entitées Nommées, de la linguistique au TAL : Statut théorique et méthodes de désambiguïsation
  • A small book on the topic: Damien Nouvel, Maud Ehrmann, Sophie Rosset, Named entities for computational linguistics, 2016, Focus, Wiley.
  • Some information about the AIDA system: https://www.mpi-inf.mpg.de/departments/databases-and-information-systems/research/ambiverse-nlu/aida

faq.title: I have noticed mistakes in the text and among the named entities. Where do they come from?
faq.summary: We use state-of-the-art tools to improve the quality of the OCR and to identify persons and locations. Inevitably, they sometimes fail and make mistakes which we need to remain aware of.
description: Generally, poor OCR also lowers the quality of the output of subsequent processes and this can often explain varying quality across different newspapers and over time.

faq.title: What is Topic Modeling?
faq.summary: Put simply, topic modeling is based on the double assumption that themes are covered by similar words in various texts and that one text can contain several themes. Inverting that assumption, we find that themes can be identified by the words that usually express them.
description: The words a text contains constitute therefore a clue to identify the themes of a text, and are given. Topic modeling helps to discover the word constellation for each document that defines a theme, or a topic, independently of the author or the point of view taken on that topic.

Doing so allows us to have an overview on the themes contained in the documents of a collection, here press articles and how many articles contain a particular theme. Topic modeling creates therefore an unsupervised, data-driven indexing of the articles, helping to navigate the whole collection. As one article can contain several topics, it is a soft clustering indexation, meaning that one article can belong to several topics and that we detect the proportion of relevant topics for a given article.

Further reading:
  • 'Ted Underwood. 'Topic Modeling Made Just Simple Enough.' The Stone and the Shell (blog), April 7, 2012. https://tedunderwood.com/2012/04/07/topic-modeling-made-just-simple-enough/.
  • MALLET homepage, http://mallet.cs.umass.edu
  • Griffiths, Thomas L., Mark Steyvers, and Joshua B. Tenenbaum. 'Topics in Semantic Representation.' Psychological Review 114, no. 2 (2007): 211–44. https://doi.org/10.1037/0033-295X.114.2.211.
  • D. M. Blei, 'Probabilistic topic models,' Commun. ACM, vol. 55, no. 4, p. 77, Apr. 2012, https://m-cacm.acm.org/magazines/2012/4/147361-probabilistic-topic-models/fulltext?mobile=true.

faq.title: How to read the topics?
faq.summary: The topics created by the topic modeling applied on the whole impresso collection help gather insights into the distribution of themes across the corpus.
description: As it is data-driven and not following a predefined list of topics, it helps to understand what are the themes present in the press articles over time.  Moreover, what makes the topics informative, is the combination of words they put forward. For instance, when searching for “butter” in the topic list, we have two results, indicating each a different use of that word.

A first use seems to derive from an agricultural context (in association with agriculture, wheat, milk, harvest), whereas the second, more from a cooking context (in association with sugar, meat, apples). Therefore topic modeling takes into account the polysemy of words and helps differentiate their uses.
On the topic page, you can explore the most relevant articles connected to a topic and get a better understanding of what articles are behind a given topic.

faq.title: Why did you apply topic modeling to this collection?
faq.summary: For the impresso interface, we use topic modeling first and foremost as a technique to help make sense of the mass of results they encounter when facing digitized sources.
description: Rather than as results ready for interpretation, we use topic models for a better understanding of the composition of the impresso corpus and to allow its navigation.  In practice that means that we use topics as facets in the Search interface so as to make a large number of search results more manageable. You can do this by either explicitly including topics of interest or by excluding topics which are not of interest (of course together with the other filters available to you).

When trying to find horoscopes, for example, one might start with searching for the keyword “horoscope”. It turns out however, that this word is still relatively polysemic and the first hits contain both actual horoscopes and other types of articles, such as advertisements, fiction etc.

Looking at the topics, the most prominent one seems to be “fear, risk, attention, partner”, which echoes potentially typical horoscope contents. Selecting this topic does indeed show a more targeted result, containing mostly actual horoscopes. For more collection-specific topic models, impresso users can export their search results and collections as .csv files, for an example see also the blog post below.

Further reading: Nibbling at text: identifying discourses on Europe in a large collection of historical newspapers using topic modelling, https://www.c2dh.uni.lu/thinkering/nibbling-text-identifying-discourses-europe-large-collection-historical-newspapers-using

faq.title: How was topic modeling applied to this collection?
faq.summary: We generated topic models for both French and German language newspapers with the goal to optimize them for content exploration. These are the topics you see on display in the interface. Given the large size of our corpus, we can not easily re-run topic modeling on the fly for user collections. We recognize that this can be of interest to many users, if this is of interest to you, we advise you to export your collection and use your preferred topic modeling tool of choice.
description: For the global topic modeling, we used MALLET and used the following steps to prepare the data:

• Language identification
  • Linguistic processing (Lemmatization; note that historical spellings cannot currently be lemmatized correctly; terms like “Bundesrath” can therefore not be found in topic models)
  • Reduction to nouns and proper nouns in order to improve the interpretability of topics.

Topic models have been trained on articles which contain a minimum of 10 nouns. For articles with less than 10 nouns we infer topics. In this context, training means the following: Given a set of documents and a fixed number of topics, we compute topic-word and topic-document distributions that make our documents probable. Inference: Given a topic model and an unseen document, we determine a topic distribution for the document that explains its observed words best.

Large datasets like ours can not be easily processed with MALLET, instead we subsample the articles in order to be able to process them. For the sample we randomly select about 30% of the articles for French (as we did not have that much of German articles, we did not sample for this language so far).

MALLET requires us to pre-determine the number of topics it should generate. We set this number to 100. This number is arbitrary but represents our attempt to capture the complexity of the newspaper content without overburdening users by offering too many topics to inspect.

In the interface, a topic is linked to an article if its proportion is at least 2% for French and 0.5% for German (this may change to 2% in the near future). This is to ensure that topics remain distinctive and can indeed serve as search facets.
Further reading: MALLET homepage

faq.title: What are 'word embeddings'?
faq.summary: Word embeddings are dense vector representations of words, basically a list of real numbers.
description: These representations, often called ‘word embeddings’, are empirically learned on our corpus data by neural networks. These techniques are based on the assumption of distributionalism, which says ‘you shall know a word by the company it keeps’ (Firth, J. R. 1957:11). Words that occur in similar contexts will have similar meanings. In our case, similar words are either semantically related (armistice - hostilités - capitulation - co-belligérance), or they are inflection variants (gedenken - angedenken - gedenk), or simply OCR errors (Eidgenoffenschast - Eidgenossenschaft - Eidgenofsenschaft).

You can use them to add additional search terms to your query, for example you can discover synonyms or frequent OCR mistakes you should consider to get additional search results. In a future release we will add a dedicated view for the more advanced exploration of word frequencies within the corpus and over time.

Further reading:
  • Firth, John Rupert. 1957. A synopsis of linguistic theory 1930-1955. In Special Volume of the Philological Society. Oxford: Oxford University Press.
  • 'FastText - Word Representations' Accessed October 12, 2019. https://fasttext.cc/index.html.
  • Ben Schmidt. 'Vector Space Models for the Digital Humanities.' Accessed October 12, 2019. http://bookworm.benschmidt.org/posts/2015-10-25-Word-Embeddings.html.

faq.title: What are Topics in Common?
faq.summary: Each article is described by several relevant topics. In order to  recommend related articles, we choose articles with the most similar topic distribution.
description: The topics are computed per language over the whole impresso collection period, so the suggested articles may come from very different time periods, linked by the inclusionary topics. This is a means to expand your readings and make you aware of related articles that may not have appeared in the results of your initial keyword search. The topic distribution may not be exactly the same for the suggested similar articles than from article currently displayed, nonetheless main topics must have similar values.

faq.title: What does text reuse mean?
faq.summary: Text reuse detection aims at finding automatically repeated text passages in a corpus, such as multiple copies of the same article published in different newspapers.
description: A newspaper corpus contains multiple copies of the same article, identical or with slight differences from one another, as well as repetitions of smaller portions of a newspaper page (e.g. advertisement, event listings, etc.). Text reuse detection aims at identifying these copies and repetitions automatically, and yields clusters of passages that were deemed to be related with one another. What a cluster contains can vary a lot: it can group together copies of the same article that differ only with respect to OCR errors; but it can also contain portions of text that share the same ‘journalistic template’, such as ‘oroscopes’, ‘avertisements’.
Why did you apply text reuse to this collection?

Detecting text reuse in a large-scale newspaper corpus is useful in many respects:
  • 1) to identify (and possibly filter out) duplicate documents before performing further processing steps (e.g. topic modelling);
  • 2) to study the virality and spread of news;
  • 3) to study information flows, both within and across national borders;
  • 4) to allow users discover which contents, within in their own collections, generated text reuse (e.g. famous political speeches, portions of national constitutions, etc.).
How was text reuse applied to this collection?

We used the open source software passim to automatically detect text reuse. Passim was applied in two steps:
  • As a pre-processing step, we ran passim in boilerplate detection mode; this allowed us to find boilerplate content within our corpus. We define boilerplate as portions of text that get repeated within the same newspaper in a time window of a month. All content items where boilerplate text was detected are filtered out from passim’s input. This allows us to reduce the final number of detected text reuse clusters by removing some noise (i.e. boilerplate) in the input data.
  • After having removed boilerplate text, we ran the content of our corpus (76 newspapers) through passim, resulting into approx. 6 million text reuse clusters.
  • We then post-processed passim’s output to enrich the detected text reuse clusters. For each cluster, we add the following information:
  • Size: the number of passages contained in a cluster;
  • Lexical overlap: the percentage of unique tokens that all passages in a cluster have in common (all text is lowercased and punctuation is stripped).
  • Time span: time window covered by documents in the cluster, measured in number of days. It’s the difference (in days) between the publication date of the oldest and of the most recent content item in the cluster.
These pieces of information can be used as filters when browsing text reuse clusters in the page https://impresso-project.ch/app/text-reuse-clusters/.

faq.title: What is a personal collection?
faq.summary: A personal collection is a set of articles that you can save on Impresso. A collection becomes part of each article, so that you can use it as you would use any other filter, like, country of publication, publication date, language, etc.

faq.title: Why are personal collections limited to 10 000 articles?
faq.summary: We have set a limit of 10 000 articles per collection to avoid performance issues.
description: If your search returned more results, only the 10.000 most relevant items will be stored. If you need to create a collection with more items, please contact us.

faq.title: Number of passages per year
faq.summary: Displays the total count of passages per year for a given query or filter operation.
description: This gives a first indication, during which years text reuse occurred more commonly. Time sliders and precise date entry allow users to filter for exact date ranges to inspect.

faq.title: How to read histograms
faq.summary: Each histogram is divided into 100 slots and results are evenly distributed across them. In the case of lexical overlap we are dealing with percentages and 1 slot corresponds to 1%. The histogram mouseover shows the number of results for each percentage value, e.g. “value: 61%  12434 results”.
description: For the cluster size and time span filters these slots are filled and distributed depending on the total number of passages a query yields. For example, a query which yields 2000 passages is divided by the number of slots available, in this case 2000 / 100 = 20. Each slot then covers a range of 20 passages. The mouseover for the first slot then reads “range:  0-20   12434 results and for the second slot it reads “range 20-30 …” and so on.
Another example: A time span of 72700 days then corresponds to a range size of 72700 / 100 = 727. The second slot then covers the range 727 – 1454 and so on. (edited)

faq.title: Cluster size
faq.summary: Distribution of text reuse cluster sizes, i.e. the number of passages they contain.
description: This filter displays the distribution of text reuse cluster sizesand indication the highest score. The histogram groups clusters of size n and displays their sum. This gives a first indication of averages as well as outliers.

Sliders can be used to specify a cluster size range of interest. Filtering by cluster size allows to exclude or explicitly focus on outliers but different cluster sizes may also correspond to different types of content.

faq.title: Lexical overlap
faq.summary: Reveals the distribution of lexical overlap in percent.
description: Reveals the distribution of lexical overlap in percent and indicates the largest number of clusters for a given score. Extremely low lexical overlap decreases the chance to discover meaningful text reuse whilst extremely high overlap will only reveal near-copies of content and may be too restrictive for some purposes.

faq.title: Time span in days
faq.summary: Reveals the number of days between the earliest and latest publication date of articles article in text reuse clusters.
description: Reveals the number of days between the earliest and latest publication date of articles article in text reuse clusters and indicates the largest number of passages for a given score. This is an efficient approach to discover or filter for instances of slow, mid-range and rapid text reuse. The histogram groups clusters by the number of days in between publication dates and displays their sum. (edited)

faq.title: Filter by text reuse clusters
faq.summary: Allows to filter for specific text reuse clusters, sorted by number of passages.
description: List of text reuse clusters which match a given query, sorted by number of passages.

Each cluster is characterised with basic information (passages count, lexical overlap, time periods and years covered) as well as a snippet preview of the passage. Clusters can be selected manually for further inspection in the Text reuse app or in other impresso components such as Search.
